ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Extension of common Korean words, phrases, and grammar structures. Also more information on Korean culture and history.
I continued to learn the basics of communication in Korean with an added focus on prose writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Teaches common phrases, words, and grammar structures.

I was glad that this course met every day for added language exposure. I was displeased with the confusing and often disrupted nature of the course schedule. For example, on days when quizzes were scheduled, we often did not have quizzes. I prepared for these quizzes and felt like my preparation time was not respected. Moreover, the course schedule was written in language that was not clear (e.g. broken English), thus it was difficult on many days to understand what was expected of me.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want to learn more Korean and have a basic level of knowledge.
I would not recommend this course to another student because I think the instructor could have done a better job of organizing the course.
